thread.title: Struggling Student

author: news24.com
title: Struggling Student
text:
When I first heard of the protests happening I honestly thought, "Oh here we go again, another protest right before exams are due to start." Even though I had no interest in the protesting, I could not help but to follow the story.
After fully understanding the reason behind the protests I realised that this protest is for every person young and old struggling to make a better life for themselves and their families.
After being accepted as a first year student at The University of the Western Cape in the year 2010, I applied for a NSFAS bursary but was declined as I was classified as not being poor enough. My mom is employed by the government as a school teacher, my dad is employed by the government as a General Foreman at a school. And I have two younger siblings. I admit my family is more privileged than many other South African families, but a helping hand would have been appreciated.
As my matric results were not good enough for a bursary, I had to make another plan. My next option was applying for a student loan. After the second year my mom decided to save each year to pay for my studies. When my brother matriculated and made plans to study further I decided to study part time and to work full time to try and lessen the financial burden for my family.
Fast forward to 2015, I have finally made it to my third year. I'm competing my B.com degree in Finance and Information Systems and I have two subjects left to compete my degree. I just found out earlier this week that I don't qualify to write one of my exams and I am still waiting on results to find out if I qualify to write my other exam. I have a job that pays me well, but I have recently had to buy my first car so that I could actually get to work. On the one hand I'm excited because I've reached one of my goals, but I'm also half dreading my first instalment going off because I still have two years worth of student debt that I'm struggling to pay off. As well as my fees for this year.
At first I was irritated with these students protesting about fee increases. But then I realised that they are protesting so that no other South African should have to drown in student debt like I am, all because they want a better life for themselves and their families.
